trial_identification.studytitle: The effect of anesthesia administration via a face mask on olfactory function
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Does the use of face masks to administer general anesthesia affect the olfactory function of patients undergoing elective surgery?

interventions.interventions: patients who received general anesthesia administration via a face mask, post-operative olfactory function compared with pre-operative olfactory function with a smell test (connecticut chemosensory clinical research center) form assessed immediately before the beginning of operation and assessed once at 5 months after completion of the operation.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Post-operative change in olfactory functions with a smell test (connecticut chemosensory clinical research center) in patients administered anesthesia via a face mask
primaryOutcome.timepoint: assessed once at 5 months after completion of operation.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Adult patients age within 20-60 undergoing elective surgery with anesthesia applied via a face mask
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Patients with known olfactory trouble acute/chronic rhinosinusitis smoking nasal polyps nasal tumor disorders that may cause olfactory trouble (kallman, turner) head trauma septum deviation

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Istanbul Research and Education Hospital Kasap Ilyas district Org.Abdurrahman Nafiz Gurman street Postal code:34098 FATIH/ ISTANBUL

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study aims to determine whether anesthesia administration via a face mask affects olfactory function.
